column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/62110;"Land use in Europe : a methodology for policy-oriented future studies";"";"<p>The common agricultural policy (CAP) is going through a phase of significant restructuring. The original goals of the policy - already stated in 1957 - were primarily aimed at improving agricultural production and reducing consumer prices for agricultural products. The success of the CAP in achieving these goals led to a considerable increase in agricultural productivity within the EU. However
column2: with this rapid development a number of negative external effects of agricultural production activities have also become apparent. The original CAP goals
column4: no longer suffice when it comes to facing the problems encountered in present-day agriculture. Effects on social structure
column5: on nature and landscape and on the environment have led to the identification of new policy goals to deal with these drawbacks. With the steadily increasing claim on the budget of the EU
column6: the call for restructuring the CAP has become even more prominent.<p>The call for new objectives alone was not enough to facilitate the process of restructuring. Many of the actual proposals to change the CAP are restricted to relatively minor changes to the instruments used. Nobody is really willing to give up policies that have led to a healthy agricultural sector with reasonable incomes for the farmers
column7: reasonably stable internal markets
column8: a guaranteed food supply and reasonable consumer prices. Furthermoer
column9: the questions whether these instruments were used to attain preferred policies and whether it was possible to achieve certain combinations of compatible policy goals were never addressed. However
column10: recent history shows that much of the new intentions within the CAP have been frustrated as a result of ongoing growth in productivity.<p>In this study the proposition is put forward that the problem with restructuring the CAP concerns the CAP's relative ignorance of future possibilities. To overcome this lack of information the possibilities are investigated to set up a future study that brings to light a conceivable and feasible mix of policy goals. Methods from future studies research are critically surveyed so as to develop an adequate methodology for this purpose. It is concluded that an explorative approach based on the description of the properties of the agricultural production system combined with additional information about the external conditions of the system might indicate the technical feasibilities of this system. However
column11: if the consequences of different policy goals for future developments in land-based agriculture are to be identified
column12: the exploration should also incorporate the identification of these policy factors in the guise of an optimisation exercise. This combination of a technical exploration of feasibilities and a political optimisation of goals is denoted as a 'pragmatic' methodology to underline the observation that it is neither the technical possibilities that shape the future
column13: nor the political aims
column14: but a mixture of the two.<p>This methodology is then applied to the case of future land-use in the EU. The technical possibilities for land-based agriculture in the EU are quantified by combining agronomic information on the relation between plant properties and production potentials
column15: information on soil properties and historical observations of the weather. First
column16: a crop growth simulation model is used to assess the potential yield of various indicator crops. This simulation model uses information on crop characteristics
column17: on quality of the soil and on properties of the climate as its inputs. Next
column18: the potential yields of indicator crops are translated into cropping systems that comprise a certain rotation scheme
column19: certain management decisions and a certain use of inputs. This translation requires information on possible farming systems and cultivation methods as additional inputs and is based on an expert judgement. Finally
column20: the technical possibilities are confronted with political wishes regarding the performance of the agricultural system. Requirements for various policy goals related to land-use together with alternative cropping systems and a demand for agricultural produce are used to construct the linear programming model GOAL (General Optimal Allocation of Land-use).<p>With this model four contrasting scenarios of future land-use in the EU are developed
column21: based on four different political philosophies: free trade and free market
column22: regional development
column23: nature and landscape conservation and environmental protection. To that end eight policy goals have been incorporated in the model: maximisation of yield per hectare
column24: maximisation of total labour
column25: minimisation of deviation from current regional distribution of labour
column26: minimisation of total pesticide use
column27: minimisation of pesticide use per hectare
column28: minimisation of total N-fertiliser use
column29: minimisation of N-fertiliser use per hectare
column30: minimisation of total costs. In a stepwise procedure
column31: the individual policy goals are optimised alternately to allow for a constant feedback of the results and thus constructing different future scenarios. In this procedure choices have to be made
column32: so the scenarios will be normative by definition. The combined scenarios reflect certain preferences in policy goals and the consequences of these preferences for agricultural land-use in the EU. These results comprise the limits to the options available to the agricultural system.<p>The model calculations point to dramatic differences between the four scenarios. When it comes to land-use the highest value is some three times higher than the lowest. The difference is twofold as far as employment and use of nitrogen (total and per hectare) are concerned. Highest values for use of crop protection agents per hectare are 4 times the lowest
column33: while the totals differ by a factor of 7.<p>All four scenarios lead to a considerable reduction in agricultural area. At present about 127 million hectares are used for land-based agriculture. In the nature and landscape scenario only 26 million hectares are needed. The other scenarios also lead to a sharp reduction in the area of land required
column34: ranging from 42 million hectares in free trade and free market scenario to 76 million hectares in the regional development scenario. These results indicate that policies that aim to maintain the area of agricultural land at the current level will have to fight an increasingly fierce battle to withstand the overall trend. Similar conclusions can be drawn for the other policy goals.<p>The results of this study can be evaluated at three different levels. First
column35: a comparison can be made between the stated demands for a method to explore future possibilities in agriculture and the method that has evolved in this study. The scenarios constructed with the aid of the GOAL model explore technical possibilities to attain a set of well-founded policy objectives. These possibilities are explored by investigating the technical limitations that restrict the potentials of the agricultural sector based on well-known quantitative data. The limitations form the 'hard facts' that are needed to convince policymakers. Although some of the assumptions can be brought under discussion
column36: any adaptation would lead to a more pronounced result in terms of the scenarios. The combination of a technical assessment with a subjective optimisation has indeed given us scientifically underpinned description of limits to the growth of agricultural production and a politically retraceable optimisation of goals.<p>Second
column37: the results of the exercise reveal that model calculations like these can act as a more or less unimpeachable authority that may discipline the discussion. The optimisations of relevant policy goals obtained with the GOAL model cannot be used to bridge a perceived gap between science and policy
column38: but the outcomes can fulfil a functional role in the way in which the political issues are brought under discussion. If this is the ambition of scientific analysis in a policy context
column39: it will be very difficult to trace the precise impact of any scientific finding in the policy debate. It can be illustrated
column40: though
column41: that there are numerous issues that may benefit from this type of information.<p>Thirdly
column42: the question arises whether the methodology developed in this study may be transferred to other issues and policy domains. The basic assumption in the general approach is that it is the political process that is sovereign with respect to political choices and it is the scientific community that is sovereign with respect to analyses of order and regularity in nature (and society). This approach is truly pragmatic in the sense that it is fully understood that the analysis must provide policymakers with the best available information to facilitate an informed decision
column43: while at the same time not forgetting that 'political efficiency' will ultimately be the decisive force. Both scientific facts and political goals thus retain their identity throughout the process of analysis
column44: as appeared from our study of the future possibilities for land-based agriculture in the EU. It is in this very respect that the methodology developed in this study differs from other approaches. In other areas of research and policy
column46: it may prove much more difficult to make this distinction between scientific analysis and political optimisation. It should be considered a challenging task for policy-oriented science then to develop a similar functional distinction by trial-and-error
column47: thus opening up new possibilities. This requires
column49: that in all policy-oriented future studies facts that are prone to scientific analysis be systematically separated from more subjective assumptions and goals.<br/>";"Latesteijn

column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/41022;"Peasant women and access to land : customary law
column2: state law and gender-based ideology : the case of the Toba-Batak (North Sumatra)";"";"<p>This study is about opportunities
column3: constraints and strategies regarding access to land of peasant women who live in the changing Toba-Batak patrilineal community of North Sumatra. Their access to land is seen in the wider context of the ongoing pressure of land scarcity due to individualization
column4: statization and privatization of communal land. The study challenges the adequacy of ongoing research on peasant women's access rights to land in developing countries. It challenges first
column5: the adequacy of feminist theories in handling cross-cultural aspects of power and gender relation; secondly
column6: the adequacy of peasantry theories to deal with peasant women; and thirdly
column7: the adequacy of legal theories in understanding the complexity of plural normative orderings in developing countries.</p><p>All in all
column8: the study challenges the assumption that individual private property and control over land under the state legal framework is the ultimate way to secure the well being and empowerment of women. The objectives of the study are threefold. First
column9: to show how different normative and institutional frameworks order the allocation of land resources. Secondly
column10: to understand how colonial
column11: religious
column12: state
column13: economic and political frameworks affect women
column14: by underpinning local patterns of inequality. Thirdly
column15: to assess the possibilities for differential access rights to land by peasant women and men.</p><p>The study attempts to answer two sets of questions. The first sets of questions relates to changing familial and inter-lineage relation to land and its impact on women. How have the Toba-Batak conceptualised access rights to land over time? What changes have been brought about by the German missionaries
column16: Dutch colonial administration and post-colonial state? Do women benefit from the plural normative orderings in acquiring access rights to land? The second set of questions relates to the pressure on communal land and its impact on women. What is the importance and function of communal land in Toba-Batak society? How does control over communal land shift to the state and private investors? What are the implications of the diminishing of communal land to local villagers? What kind of overt and covert resistance do they reveal? How do they strategize their access to land in relations to the state's increasing control over land?</p><p>Following chapter one which provides the overall background of the study
column17: chapter two introduces the situation of the Toba-Batak changing society in colonial times where the inception of legal pluralism has started to occur. The first western influence
column18: Protestant Christianity
column19: introduced quot;a process of individualization and secularization"" to the Toba-Batak society . The christianization of the Toba-Batak had
column20: to a great extent
column21: smoothed the path for the Dutch to gain a strong foothold. Both the Germans and the Dutch had
column22: in different ways
column23: introduced the idea of incorporating leadership beyond the traditional spatial-lineage areas
column24: characterized by a rigid hierarchical power structure. But it was the power of the state (in this case colonial rule) that was becoming more and more central to the further process of change
column25: even though this power had been under continuous attack both by the (German) missionaries and the Toba-Batak themselves.</p><p>The western colonial influence affected all areas of life
column26: including those related to land and the position of women. Land tenure was selectively detached from its relation to the sacred nature of <em>adat</em> and from the essence of the <em>adat</em> community as ""an association of worship whose members every once in a while strengthened the union among themselves or the union with the ancestors through celebrations"". The efforts to ideologically detach land matters from the sacred nature of the <em>adat</em> created room to re-negotiate new relations to land
column27: both internally within lineage relations and externally with outside actors. The changing internal relations may concern gender
column28: as was the case with the education of female students and various more gender-neutral colonial jurisprudence. The promotion of the principle of gender equality into the Toba-Batak rigid
column29: patrilineal society is
column30: therefore
column31: to be seen in the wider process of the ""de-sacralization of adat"". Likewise
column32: the changing external land relations may be concerned with the emerging of (new) outside actors in accessing
column33: managing and allocating the local land
column34: a process in which the (colonial)state
column35: individual Bataks and non-Bataks and private companies come into the picture.</p><p>Chapter three demonstrates how contemporary Toba-Batak society is affected by the increasing power of the (post-colonial) state
column36: especially during the New Order period. The Toba-Batak has become one local part of the wider Indonesian state that tries to develop its national economy. A major attempt to pursue the unification and centralisation project of the state is through the expansion of state modern bureaucracy and administration down to village level while neutralizing the <em>adat</em> principles and authorities which are often considered inconsistent with (universal) national ideals of justice (cf.
column37: Wignjosoebroto 1994 and 1997). Contrary to the patrilineal and highly patriarchal Toba-Batak <em>adat</em>
column38: the Indonesian Constitution incorporates the principle of gender equality for all citizens. With the strengthening of state power
column39: there are competing rights and rules pertaining to land
column40: deriving from different sets of authority: the state and the <em>adat</em> . This multiplicity of rights and rules governing the land is not situated in a vacuum
column41: but in the context of a dynamic process of land concentration <em>vis-a-vis</em> land scarcity. State intervention in the process of statization and privatization has been driven by contradictory forces between national economic ambition on the one hand
column42: and the urgency for a more sustainable local resource management on the other.</p><p>Chapter four and five result from the field-work in North Sumatra. Chapter four deals with the issue of access rights to land in a relatively normal daily life situation of internal village and lineage relations
column43: based on a village study conducted in Siraja Hutagalung. Because of the pressure of land scarcity
column44: the basic traditional practice of acquiring land through clearing an empty land or forest no longer occurs. This results in the two categories of acquiring access rights to land
column45: namely the ""generational and affinal transactions"" which are heavily gender-biased and ""reciprocal and economic transactions"" which are geared towards fulfilling the function of an equitable distribution of basic livelihood
column46: augmenting economic benefits and confirming each other's political position within the kinship and residential unit. Gender-based arrangement in accessing rights to land is the foremost and the only traditional way to keep the land within the restricted boundaries of the patrilineage.</p><p>Chapter five provides an analysis of the ongoing conflicts on communal land that presently mark the relationships between the local people
column47: the state authorities and private enterprise. The chapter demonstrates how the different notions of Toba-Batak's and women's access rights to (communal)land from different levels of normative orders and institutions are challenged
column49: conceded and reconfirmed. The discussion is located in the wider context of the changing political-economy because of the incorporation into the national economy. Three cases presented
column52: indicate how peasant men and women are affected by
column53: and at the same time react to
column54: the ongoing statization and privatization process of land under the state legal framework.</p><p>In chapter six I return to conclude the various factors of change among the Toba-Batak which affect the ""layered structure of property regimes"" (Benda-Beckmann
column55: forthcoming). The multifold function attributed to land proves to be the most important factor in explaining the attitude of Toba-Batak peasant women towards the rule of patrilineality in accessing rights to land within inter-lineage and familial relations. The current shift of allocation rights over communal land from the <em>adat</em> community to the state has noticeably marginalised the residing local people and the <em>adat</em> community both in the initial process of land transfer and in the subsequent process of deciding its use and exploitation. The findings of the study support the argument that the state development policy and practice often place more emphasis on the economic function of land while neglecting other functions a communal land might have for the local people. For women
column56: it is the temporal dimension of the socio-economic security aspect of communal land affecting their reproductive task which is at stake in the process of land expropriation.</p><p>I discuss some theoretical implications of the study. Rather than looking at kinship as a clear-cut and self-evident factor of hindering gender-equality or enabling it
column57: the empirical study on Toba-Batak society has suggested that kinship simultaneously functions as both enabling and hindering factor for women's access rights to land under different circumstances. I am of the opinion that there is no such thing as gender solidarity among Toba-Batak women because their identity is shaped more by their kinship affiliation and position of seniority within kinship ranks rather than simply by gender. On the other hand
column58: it is the resistance of peasant women against any outside intervention that makes the Toba-Batak struggle over communal land into a basic struggle over both resources and meanings as well as a struggle that shapes the borderline between the local groups' interests and that of the private investors <em>vis-a-vis</em> the state.</p><p>The study also indicates that legal pluralism is a fact while the claim that state law is the only law is rather mythical. Based on this
column59: the study concludes that gender-equality claim that state legal structures and norms directly cause and determine action for the betterment of women is highly questionable. The introduction of state law into matters related to land tends to detach land rights from wider social relationships
column60: thereby neutralizing the restriction to endow land to women as well as the alienation of land to outsiders. These are seen in principal as opposing their Toba-Batak adat of patrilineality. On the other hand
column61: in the cases relating to the expropriation of communal
column62: the state law and judiciary system are seen as threatening rather than defending the interests of peasant women and the local community against the interests of private investors.</p>";"Simbolon

column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/40764;"In the name of the land : organization
column3: and the culture of the state in a Mexican Ejido";"";"<p>This study is based on research carried out during several periods from mid 1991 to mid 1995 in the ejido La Canoa in Jalisco
column4: western Mexico
column5: and in several government agencies. The study focuses in particular on the period between the 1930s and 1992 when the Mexican agrarian law was fundamentally changed. The last chapters of the book discuss the change of the agrarian law in 1992.</p><p>The study shows how over the years organizing practices developed with respect to the access to ejido plots and the management of the ejido which differed from the prescriptions of the law. For example
column6: the division of the arable plots
column7: the selling of these plots
column8: renting them out
column9: or leaving them unused were all illegal practices which became common in ejidos throughout Mexico. It also became a common phenomenon that instead of the ejido assembly
column10: in which all ejidatarios are represented
column11: the head of the ejido
column12: the commissioner
column13: took decisions on his own. Likewise
column14: the rules were also seldom applied in the resolution of land conflicts by the Ministry of Agrarian Reform (MAR). Land conflicts between ejidatarios and private land owners abound and many have never been resolved. In this study the conflict of the ""lost land"" is discussed. This concerns a conflict over land that officially belongs to the ejido La Canoa but which since the thirties has been in the hands of several private landholders.</p><p>In this book it its argued that the labeling of the above mentioned practices in a functionalist way as ""disorganized"" or ""corrupt"" forms part of modernist discourses of development and does not bring us any nearer to an understanding of these dynamics
column15: nor to an insight into the precise role played by the official rules and formal institutions. It is argued that these practices are the result of active organizing by ejidatarios
column16: as well as officials and other social actors. Furthermore
column17: it is shown that in the myriad of activities which are labeled as ""illegal""
column18: ""disorganized""
column19: and ""corrupt"" we can also distinguish certain organizing patterns. For example
column20: in chapter five it was shown that in the many ""illegal"" arrangements with ejido plots we can distinguish a certain pattern in the way these were organized and that in these arrangements other ejidatarios
column21: officials of the MAR
column22: the ejido commissioner
column23: and the ejido assembly play specific roles.</p><p>In chapter six a different form of patterning of organizing practices has been discussed. There it was shown
column24: among other things
column25: that the executive committee of the ejido never renders accounts of their activities at public ejido meetings
column26: but that alternative forms of accountability exist and other effective mechanisms by which the ejidatarios control their executive committee. Namely
column27: through informal channels
column28: gossips
column29: and regional political networks. In this context the ejido meetings have turned into arenas for bickering and confrontation and have developed symbolic roles in distinguishing between ""insiders"" and ""outsiders"". At the same time the official ejido structure becomes important in the case of serious conflicts. Then the ""formal game is played"" together with the use of informal political pressures.</p><p>It is argued that this structuring of organizing practices in unexpected and often ""invisible"" ways always occurs around the management of resources
column30: and in relation to institutional settings. This book sets out the way that all forms of organizing take place in wider force fields. A force field is defined as a field of power and struggle between different social actors around certain resources or problems and around which certain forms of dominance
column31: contention
column32: and resistance may develop
column33: as well as certain regularities and forms of ordering. The assumption is that all forms of organizing
column34: even the most ""private"" or ""illegal"" ones
column35: develop within fields of power. In this view
column36: the patterning of organizing processes which we may find are not the result of a common understanding or normative agreement
column37: but of the forces at play within the field.</p><p>It has been shown that the development of forms of ordering in organizing practices is closely related to forms of exclusion of certain social categories. Different groups can be distinguished with differing roles
column38: different access to resources
column39: and differing rights. The concept of force field also helps us to analyze the precise role of the law and official procedures.</p><p>The assumptions is that multiple force fields exist which develop their own dynamic and have different specific implications for the people involved. This means that in relation to certain resources and problems ejidatarios may develop a high degree of autonomy
column40: while around others they have little ""room for manoeuvre"". The organizing practices around the arable plots in the ejido led to much autonomy for the ejidatarios
column41: though the law
column42: the bureaucratic procedures and the officials were always present as a ""distant threat"". On the other hand
column43: the bureaucracy has been much less present in relation to organizing in the common lands. Around the commons ejidatarios and landless villagers have great autonomy to act without interference from the state bureaucracy. While
column44: around the arable land and the commons the ejidatarios have developed a high degree of autonomy
column45: around the ""lost land"" they obviously operate in a force field in which they are relatively powerless. There we find ejidatarios in a hopeless fight against private landowners. Hence
column46: we cannot talk in a generalized way about the structural position of ejidatarios vis-á-vis regional elites
column47: or about the nature of their relation with the Mexican state. This differs according to the resources and problems at stake.</p><p>In this approach
column50: and story-telling by social actors are considered to be a central part of the organizing process. These dialogues reflect a continuous active engagement of social actors with the world around them. Furthermore
column51: the creation and re-creation of stories are considered to be a way of ordering the world around us and of arriving at the best strategies to be followed in the organizing process. Organizing practices are always related to the production of meaning and in this book it has been shown how the organizing practices around different resources in specific force fields are accompanied by reflective talk
column54: and the production of multiple meanings through imagination and the work of interpretation. These dialogues reflect forms of struggle
column56: and resistance in relation to existing organizing practices and relations of power.</p><p>As has been shown in this book
column57: ejidatarios have a complicated and contradictory relation with the Mexican state. The state was their ally in the fight against the hacendados during the period of agrarian reform and it has also been the provider of all kinds of services (schools
column60: in other instances the state is viewed as a corrupt and violent enemy which is greatly feared and distrusted by the people. Hence
column61: we have an image of the Mexican state as the protector and oppressor of the ejidatarios at the same time. Images of the state conjoin notions of evil with goodness. For that reason
column62: the ejidatarios may be supportive and enthusiastic towards the Mexican President at one moment
column63: and cynical and distrustful about his speeches at another moment. Or they can laugh about themselves being deceived by the democratic and liberalizing discourse of a president who later on proved to be one of the worst swindlers the country ever saw. The ejidatarios can be proud of being part of the Mexican nation-state project but at the same time they can criticize powerholders for their corruption and for their squeezing of the peasants.</p><p>I have argued that the continuous theorizing about power and politics in society not only concerns a rationalization of actions but also an investment in the ""idea of the state""
column65: an investment in the belief of the existence of a center of control. This does not mean that practices of authority and control do not exist but that people tend to look for a coherence and logic which does not exist. These imaginations which are constitutive of the ""culture of the state""
column66: are based upon experiences and are mediated by a series of governmental techniques and by the media
column68: and movies. The ""culture of the state"" is central to the operation of the bureaucracy as a ""hope-generating machine"". The ""hope-generating machine"" gives the message that everything is possible
column70: and that things will be different from now on. This permeates all aspects of life and triggers powerful responses. However
column71: rather than producing a certain rationality and coherence
column74: fears and expectations. Although people are never naive
column75: during certain periods they can become inspired and enthusiastic about new programs and new openings that are offered to them. Yet
column76: doubts never totally disappear.</p><p>It is also argued that in this context of a decentered ""hope-generating machine"" without a clear center and coherence
column77: brokers do often not play a role in effectively connecting ejidatarios to ""the state""
column78: but play a role in the imagination of state power. By suggesting that they are the ""right connection"" to higher levels and to the ""center of control"" brokers contribute to the ""idea of the state"". In the same way
column79: by searching for the ""right connection"" which can help them to resolve their problems
column80: ejidatarios invest in the ""idea of the state"". Ejidatarios and bureaucrats are implicated in the cultural representation of the state through processes of rationalization
column83: etc. but also through processes of fetishization
column84: that is the attribution to certain objects such as maps and documents with special powers. In this complex of desire and fantasy
column85: inscription is very important. People develop a fetishism around certain official documents
column86: even when they cannot ""read"" these documents according to official standards.</p><p>The same can be said of bureaucrats who tend to reify the law
column87: in spite of ""knowing"" that official procedures do not play a central role in the outcome of highly politicized land conflicts. In these processes
column88: the ""idea of the state"" is objectivized and fixed in maps
column91: see a ""re-enchantment of governmental techniques"" as they acquire symbolic meanings beyond their administrative functions.</p>";"Nuijten

column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/39228;"Analyzing alternative policy instruments for the irrigation sector : an assessment of the potential for water market development in the Chishtian Sub-division
column2: Pakistan";"";"<br/>The increasing scarcity of water and financial resources has made the economic dimension of water an important element of irrigation sector policies. Water pricing is the means traditionally used to incorporate economic issues into irrigation sector policies. More recently
column3: water markets have been proposed as an alternative to water pricing. From a theoretical point of view
column4: water markets are expected to lead to an efficient allocation of water among water users
column5: as well as to improve water use economic efficiency. However
column6: the discrepancy between theoretical requirements and the existing characteristics of the irrigation sector is significant. Therefore
column7: the potential for water markets in managing water resources is questioned.<p>In Pakistan
column8: consideration has recently been given to water markets as a means to improve the performance of irrigated agriculture. The present study investigates issues related to water markets in Pakistan using the example of the Chishtian Sub-division
column9: an irrigation system located in the South-Punjab. Within the framework of an integrated approach that combines hydraulic
column10: soil and economic issues
column11: the study analyses the functioning and impact of existing surface and groundwater markets that have developed spontaneously within the tertiary units of the irrigation system. Although constraints remain on the functioning of these markets
column12: water transactions significantly improve the flexibility in managing water resources without threatening significantly the sustainability of irrigated agriculture.<p>This study also discusses elements related to the technical feasibility of water markets at higher spatial scales in the irrigation system
column13: and their potential impact on agricultural production and the physical environment. The potential for reallocation of surface water in terms of increased farm gross income is the highest within and between tertiary units. Also
column14: the impact of reallocation on farm gross income is higher when volumes of surface water are transacted independently of the time of the year
column15: as opposed to yearly reallocations that would affect proportionally the supply of canal water received each month. Constraints related to the existing conveyance infrastructure are not seen as a major obstacle to water transactions. Changes in the operational rules required to develop water markets at higher spatial scales
column16: however
column17: may represent an important constraint to water market development. Also
column18: the absence of storage facility limit the potential for temporal reallocation of surface water
column19: thus the overall impact of potential water markets.<p>The thesis concludes by emphasizing the importance of a combination of interventions to manage the irrigation sector
column20: as well as to improve its performance in terms of agricultural production and sustainability. The need to analyze
column21: compare and combine interventions
column22: further stresses the relevance of an integrated approach that integrates disciplines
column23: links decisional and bio-physical processes
column24: and investigates the heterogeneity of these processes within the irrigation system.";"Strosser

column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/458279;"Actualisatie van de grondwatertrappenkaart van het Land van Cuijk met een gestratificeerde tweefasensteekproef en regressieschatters";"";"Om het effect van de ruilverkavelingswerken op de grondwaterstand in het Land van Cuijk te bepalen zijn de bestaande grondwatertrappen geactualiseerd. Hiertoe is het gebied naar grondwatertrap
column2: grondsoort en te verwachten effect van de ingrepen onderverdeeld in 26 homogene gebieden (strata). Met een gestratificeerde tweefasesteekproef en regressieschatters is van elk stratum de gemiddelde waarde geschat van de gemiddeld hoogste (GHG) en de gemiddeld laagste grondwaterstand (GLG). Op de geactualiseerde grondwatertrappenkaart komen vrijwel uitsluitend grondwatertrappen voor met een GHG dieper dan 40 cm beneden maaiveld. Er zijn sterke aanwijzingen dat vooral de GHG flink gedaald is.";"Riele

column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/28936;"Law and peasant communities in Peru (1969 - 1988)";"";"<p>In this final chapter we see how the legalization of the community and its lands -or the failure to achieve this situation- managed to push
column2: modify or stop some social processes which had been taking place within the communities being studied. Some of these changes were expected by the <em>comuneros</em> while others were not. Nevertheless these processes should be seen from a wider point of view
column3: to permit us to draw conclusions about some key questions presented in the investigation. For example
column4: what
column5: finally
column6: is the idea of community that predominates within the State and for the <em>comuneros?</em> Is <em></em> our idea of legal pluralism adequate or not to explain all these processes? Did socio-legal interactions between peasant and State bureaucrats end with the legalization
column7: or did they assume another form? What can be expected from this relation achieved between communities and the State?<p>Although some of these questions have already been touched upon in the previous chapters
column8: we wish here to draw up a final synthesis to permit us to draw theoretical conclusions on the subjects of our research. To this end some important empirical conclusions are presented
column9: arising from the earlier analysis
column10: in order to go back to the theoretical ideas presented initially
column11: re-elaborating them and amplifying them in some cases.<p><strong>The Effects of Legalization on the State and the Community</strong><p>With the Agrarian Reform process
column12: State recognition began to be important to the peasants. Authors like Brandt (1987:b)
column13: Costa (1981)
column14: Del Castillo (1987)
column15: Figallo (1986) and Pásara (1978 and 1988) have written about legalization earlier. But they see the importance of this process mainly in the sense that recognition is a legal resource of the communities to avoid any abuse by or conflict with <em>haciendas</em> or other elite local and regional groups. However
column16: my study analyses legalization differently
column17: in a wider process
column18: relating it to ideas of legal pluralism and socio-legal interactions between peasants and the State
column19: among other issues.<p>The liquidation of the <em>hacienda</em> regime began to give this possibility new meaning:the legalization began to be seen also as a way to ensure a response from the State to a set of problems that had begun to confront the <em>comuneros:</em> lack of lands
column20: migration to urban centres
column21: lack of basic services
column22: loss of authorities' legitimacy
column23: individualism
column24: etc. Hence
column25: recognition
column26: registration and titling of lands began to be considered as an important issue by the communities.<p>As shown in previous chapters
column27: the legalization process influenced several aspects of communal life
column28: such as communal infrastructure
column29: irrigation systems
column30: financial aid
column31: productivity
column32: etc. Most of these improvements would not have been made without the State's intervention
column33: which shows that
column34: to a certain degree
column35: the <em>comuneros</em> achieved their objective of ensuring State aid through these mechanism. However
column36: not even this aid could reverse some of the processes -such as the pressure to migrate- that were based on more global factors.<p>Secondly
column37: to be successful in the legalization process
column38: the <em>comuneros</em> had to have the right ""spirit"". This turned out to be an important factor
column39: because it permitted various problems encountered during the process to be resolved. In this sense
column40: the historical factor and the geographical features play an important role
column41: because they permitted maintaining certain forms of integration and identity among the members of the community
column42: which had been fading away due to the problems mentioned above. The success of legalization strengthened the communal spirit and also provided the communal organization with new vitality.<p>Thirdly
column43: the legalization process also played an important role in the change and transformation of the Andean cosmo-vision. New patterns of conduct
column45: beliefs and values are being constantly introduced
column46: changing the shape of peasant communities. This influence can also differ between communities located near the roads going to important markets
column47: and others located in very poor Andean zones.<p>Finally
column48: although Paroccan did not have significant problems with its neighbours concerning boundaries
column49: in most of the rural zones there were constant conflicts between communities or with third parties over the possession of lands. This meant that the stages of agreements were dismissed
column50: or that the State Court decisions did not end the conflict. The Law of Titling of Peasant Communities
column52: did not solve all these boundary problems
column53: but only formalized the property of the communities that could reach agreement with their neighbours. Such was the case of Paroccan
column54: which finally obtained title deeds from the State.<p>However
column55: the communal organization was not the only beneficiary of the legalization. The State also managed to partly reinforce its legitimacy and importance within legalized communal spaces
column56: as can be seen in the case of the conflict resolution system. The cases presented in the preceding chapter show that the the selection of State courts to resolve conflicts was greatly stimulated
column57: and it even stopped being foreign to the community. Nevertheless
column58: most of the <em>comuneros</em> kept on choosing the local conflict-resolving system. Moreover
column59: legal pluralism is weak in the cases of felonies or crime
column60: unlike in other countries. For example
column62: there is total subordination to State law; in land conflicts both systems prevail; in family conflicts the local Andean law has priority.<p><strong>The Land Tenure System in the Communities</strong><p>The land tenure system has changed considerably within the peasant communities. There are several issues to take into account when explaining these changes. The first is to consider the geographical area in which the community is located
column63: its accessibility and the type of resources that a community has
column65: etc. A second issue is formed by the common features that peasant communities have in a specific region or sub-region
column66: and the relationships between them and with other social actors on a regional level. A third important issue is to understand the categories and concepts used in the description and analysis of the Andean land tenure system. The concepts of ""individual"" or ""collective"" are easier to explain in a western economy
column67: but not in the Andean one.<p>During the Inca period
column68: the <em>ayllus</em> were developed within a context in which the concept of ""property"" was associated with the idea of ""State"". Social differentiation was clearly established between the Inca's family
column71: State officials and the Indian population
column72: and it certainly existed also within the <em>ayllu</em> itself
column73: despite its apparent homogeneity.<p>The same assumptions have been made in studies about the Indian communities during the time of Spanish rule. The whole society was socially differentiated
column74: because differences were considered inherent to humanity
column75: and differentiation was a policy followed by the Spaniards. The lend tenure system changed during this period
column76: the best lands being awarded to the Spaniards while
column77: after the concentration of the indigenous people in <em>reducciones
column78: </em> their territorial rights were recognized but this did not necessarily signify a collective property of the land.<p>Concerning the Republican period
column79: we recall that the <em>criollos</em> gained control of the government
column80: Spanish rule ended and important changes in the social and political structure took place. Here the social and political differentiation was no longer primarily upheld for racial reasons
column82: but rather was based on wealth
column83: contacts in the different economic and political spheres
column84: handling of knowledge and technology and the ability to transport goods both horizontally and vertically.<p>In this period
column85: the land tenure system was based on the existence of large landholders and owners of sugar <em>haciendas
column86: </em> who controlled political power until the land reform of 1969. Many of these <em>haciendas</em> and big landholdings were formed at the time of the appropriation
column88: of communal lands. Communal lands were finally reduced to the poorest and highest lands
column89: such as occurred in Cuzco. The constitutional recognition of the communities as from 1921 which granted communal lands their inalienable character
column90: did not stop this process which could only finally be stopped by the Agrarian Reform.<p>In this reform
column91: the communal organization was considered an important element in the landholding system. The communal domain was respected
column92: since it had been decided that the communities should regain unexploited parcels. The community's primacy in the organization of activities dealing with agricultural production was also allowed. That is to say
column93: the Agrarian Reform recognized the community as a unit of production. But it also recognized that other associative forms
column96: and preferred this model to the communal one in order to apply it to the peasants' community. Perhaps the Statute on the Peasant Communities contains the widest recognition of customary norms. It authorized the ruling of the community's regime by traditional norms
column97: but also limited the customary rights over lands
column98: pastures and waters. This meant a restriction on the operation of customary law
column99: since it minimized its effectiveness and objectives.<p>The land tenure system in Peru has changed significantly since the land reform. Most of the cooperatives and other associative forms such as SAIS have now been dissolved
column100: different social types of small landowners have been created. The large extensions of landholdings have not been completely abandoned
column102: especially since the economic crisis deepened in the 1980s and the presence of terrorist groups such as Shining Path was felt. Nevertheless
column103: in recent decades the communities have shown an extraordinary capacity for survival.<p><strong>Andean Law and Conflict Resolution</strong><p>Andean law becomes manifest concretely in my research locations. Because it may be rather different in other Andean regions which make no part of my research
column104: the following ideas refer to the notion and assumptions over possible manifestations of Andean law rather than a descriptive analysis.<p>Andean local law does not need external enforcement. It is legitimised and enforced by the same social groups that enact it. People identify themselves with their rules
column106: sanctions and decisions. When one of their institutions is old fashioned
column107: peasants just change it. That is why Andean law is alive and continuously changing.<p>This allegiance to their legal institutions does not mean they would not look also for State law support when necessary. However
column108: the peasants deal with it in a contradictory way. While asserting the value and effectiveness of their own legal institutions
column109: they feel also an urgency to anchor their claims and positions in official law. There seems to be a functional division in this regard. Peasants do not apply the Civil law framework to their marriages
column111: but they employ State law in emergency cases
column112: once conflict or disagreement has developed. Consequently
column113: the <em>peasants do not</em> ignore State law
column115: but they are somewhat reluctant to accept it completely. As I have observed
column116: even in processes aimed at benefitting peasant communities there is resistance towards exogenously originated procedures.<p><em>Comuneros</em> do not consider State law as a way of preventing conflicts. They mostly use it as an <em>a posteriori</em> device
column117: probably because cultural reasons prevent them from incorporating State legal structures. Some scholars suggest that peasants not only ignore State law
column118: but do so deliberately from ignorance.<p>Peasants usually do not trust judges and State officials. Their experience when dealing with them has been quite distressing. State authorities
column120: supported the <em>hacendados</em> against the interests and possessions of the peasantry. Even though <em>haciendas</em> have disappeared
column121: State officials have still failed to understand and support peasants. When there is a power or wealth differential vis-à-vis non-local parties
column122: <em>comuneros</em> expect judges and authorities to favour the richer parties.<p>Within this context
column123: peasants are willing to submit their grievances to their own institutions and procedures. After all
column124: their conflict resolution mechanisms have important advantages over the official ones: easy access
column127: shared language and cultural code and closeness of the people involved. At the same time
column128: peasants can approach their traditional authorities with less awe and feelings of uncertainty than state authorities.<p>It is important to point out that peaceful coexistence is a permanent goal in peasants' interactions. In most cases
column129: proceedings try to find the real problems behind the explicit demands and claims. This method allows the opponents to recognize the deep causes of their controversy and to seek a satisfactory agreement. If they cannot find it
column130: the authority's final decision usually is to propose a compromise. The parties have to make concessions to each other. And both receive a partial solution to their claims.<p>Using the same logic
column131: peasants try to solve not only the problem <em>sub litis</em>
column132: but to prevent new disagreements from arising. Therefore
column133: authorities pay special attention to victims' situation
column134: and to the need to compensate them for damages. Sometimes compensations can be just symbolic
column135: but they express a way of solving moral or non-material problems. In some cases the answer is not to propose any solution
column136: but to delay the decision of the authority. Peasants think this will allow the parties to examine the matter more carefully and less passionately in order to reach a solution through direct bargaining.<p>When there is an action opposed to the communal interest
column137: the sanction is aimed at reintegrating the trespasser into the community. <em>Comuneros</em> give their verdicts an educational purpose. Changes of attitude can be achieved by the imposition of a fine
column138: by forced communal work or by a short period in the communal jail. A common psychological punishment is based on public humiliation that induces shame in the trespasser. Punishments are applied with an admonitory objective. Physical punishment is still present in some communities. If the transgressor does not show a real desire to better his conduct
column139: he can receive the strongest sanction of all: expulsion from the community. In the Andean world
column140: this is almost as serious as a death sentence
column141: because nobody can survive alone. Thus
column142: other sanctions can be considered as ways of preventing the trespasser from being cast out by his social group.<p>The enforcement of sanctions is not universal. Unlike occidental law
column143: peasants do not set the same abstract measure of punishment for everyone. Their decisions are based on all they know about the subject involved
column144: on the personal characteristics and individual and social background. Consequently
column145: when the transgressor is a foreigner
column146: the decision is also different. Peasants often see the foreign trespasser as an aggressor against communal order and the <em>comuneros'</em> goods and lives.<p><strong>Common Problems
column147: Common Solutions</strong><p>We can point out several problems shared by the communities being studied
column148: and which should be solved soon. These problems relate principally to the communities' integration into the market and their relationship with the Central State. The solutions necessarily have to involve a redefinition of the relationship existing between the Andean and the State legal systems.<p>As we have seen
column149: the communities studied have their own particular problems
column150: but they share certain other problems which affect most of the peasant communities in Peru. Among the latter problems we can point out three of the most relevant quandaries: the weakening of the communal organization
column151: the scarcity of lands and the great expectations of the <em>comuneros</em> regarding State aid. We can add a fourth
column152: which derives from the above mentioned three: the absence of alternatives.<p>The first problem -the continuing weakening of the communal organization- is caused by the lack of participation in labour and communal work groups
column153: lack of interest in attending communal assemblies
column154: tension and struggles among the different power groups
column155: the migration of adults and youngsters
column156: the generation conflict and growing distrust of directive authorities. As we can see
column157: many of these factors have nothing to do with the internal dynamics of the community
column159: like the rising cost of living and the lack of job opportunities within the community.<p>This results in increasing hardships for communities like Paroccan that experience
column160: for instance in the application of social control mechanisms over its members and their resources
column161: a tendency towards breaking-up of the communal bond that holds the members of the community together. On the other hand
column162: what really matters is the fact that
column164: the <em>comuneros</em> themselves have noticed how important it is to obtain or keep a communal organization capable of defending themselves against common problems
column165: such as the drop in market prices for the crops they cultivate
column166: thereby filling a gap which the State is not interested in dealing with.<p>The second problem is also shared by both the communities we have studied. This refers to the lack of available lands within the community. It is a problem that gets worse in those cases where there is great number of youngsters
column167: poor quality land and the impossibility of expanding the boundaries of the communal territory. The consequences
column169: are increasing tensions among the <em>comuneros</em> (or peasants
column170: in the case of Ccachabamba). These tensions are present among the rich and poor (criteria established regarding how much land each one holds)
column171: or between the younger and older <em>comuneros.</em> When there is a strong organization
column172: as in the case of Paroccan
column173: it can mediate in order to reduce or even stop the conflicts
column174: but there is not much it can do to solve the real conflict
column175: in which a solution can be achieved only by acquiring more land.<p>As Hopkins (1990:17) points out
column176: when it comes to this problem
column177: the peasants usually propose that in the first place there should be a restructuring or redistribution of the communal lands. In the second place
column178: they propose more intensive usage of agricultural lands
column179: by means of new cultivating techniques. However
column180: their first suggestion would require a restructuring parallel to the power relations within the community
column181: something that is very hard to achieve without breaking the communal unit itself. The second Suggestion
column183: will not solve the problem of land distribution.<p>We feel that the above is a problem which requires even more attention than the scholars are giving it
column184: mainly because we feel that it would be in touch with the government's objectives for incorporating communal lands into the land market.<p>This leads us to the government's role in the communities' issue. In his work
column185: Hopkins concludes that:<br/>""The peasant expects too much from the State. Many of the alternatives proposed depend directly on the government's actions. This is expressed in economic problems
column186: and in technical and social aspects as well"" (1990:19).<p>Our research shows the truth behind this assertion. In this way
column187: the peasants' quest for recognition and titling is just one way to secure an answer to their problems from the State. But we have also seen that this answer depends a great deal on the interest or needs which the State has in this social sector
column188: which is why these expectations are not met most of the time
column192: legalization of the community should not be the only goal. What the community requires is to strengthen the communal organization's mediator role in relation to the State
column193: using it to demand more access to land
column198: etc. This turns out to be even more necessary in a political context in which the State is trying to ignore its social role in the most needy sectors.<p>Finally
column199: we have the problem regarding alternatives: in other words
column200: in what way can the <em>comuneros</em> find adequate solutions to these and other serious problems affecting them? Hopkins is not optimistic about this: to him
column201: the peasants show little capacity for finding solid and precise alternatives (1990:15). We have seen
column203: that after various centuries of domination and imposition
column204: the communities have always found creative and talented ways for survival. Because of this
column205: we believe the communities will finally find the way to keep their autonomy and their vitality
column206: even though this seems practically impossible
column207: considering the actual context (Bonilla 1987; Caballero 1990; Figueroa 1987; Gonzáles de Olarte 1986; Mallon 1983).<p><strong>Theoretical Conclusions</strong><p><strong><em>State Bureaucracy and Peasant Communities</em></strong><p>In our research special attention is given to the behaviour of the different levels of bureaucratic offices in charge of communal demands
column208: and to strategies developed by the peasants in order to achieve their objectives.<p>Considering this issue
column209: we think that the varied behaviour of the State's administration
column211: must be more deeply analysed. There are two issues that deserve special attention: On the one hand the form in which the different levels of public administration in Peru organize and make connections; and on the other hand
column212: the rationality that dominates this organization. One of the main features of the Peruvian State is its centralism. It is Lima -thus referring to a particular regionwhere the most important decisions are made
column213: where development models and the normative framework of such models are elaborated. Then
column214: the central authorities try to impose these models in the different regions
column216: regardless of whether the model is adequate to that reality. In this case
column217: what they are trying to do is adapt the reality to the model
column219: and the supremacy given to the model over the reality
column220: impedes smooth communication between the different bureaucratic levels
column221: and between bureaucracy as a whole with society. Problems that can be emerge at the local level are not seen as deficiencies in the model
column222: but as errors or incapacity of the officials charged with applying it. Depending on each particular case
column223: this conception can have the consequence that the lower levels -street level bureaucratsbecome more accessible

Perhaps the final fate of peasant communities in Peru is very related to the results and proposals that might result from these studies.<p><strong><em>The Concept of Community</em></strong><p>One of the most important conclusions in our study is that the term ""community"" denotes different realities

column287: but in some cases also harmful.<p>The mutual influences between both legal systems leads us to the question of juridical pluralism and to the relations that may be maintained by State law and Andean law at different levels of social organisation. In the case of our study
column288: the State establishes from the beginning a legal repertoire which is going to interact with the community's own legal repertoire during certain small processes like the legalization process

column294: the legalization process not only influences the behaviour of individuals and groups participating in the process
column295: but it also puts into effect a <em>symbolic</em> process which transforms or gives new sense and significance to legal values
column296: both for the community as well as for the State

column304: scholars should give more attention to this aspect. Therefore
column305: the legalization process brings about a link between the State and the peasant communities which goes deeper than the formal bond. The peasant community turns into a legal institution. This link may extend through time in a continuous interaction process

column2: management and decision-making";"";"<p>Although there is a growing awareness about the many benefits of natural ecosystems
column3: concrete information on their full economic value is still scarce. This thesis provides a comprehensive method whereby all functions and values of natural and semi-natural ecosystems can be assessed and evaluated in a systematic manner. A checklist of 37 environmental functions is given with examples of the functions and socio-economics value of three major types of ecosystems: tropical moist forests (based on a case study of the Darien National Park
column4: a pre-montane rainforest on the border between Panama and Colombia)
column5: wetlands (based on a case study of the Dutch Wadden Sea) and an oceanic
column6: volcanic island ecosystem: the Galapagos National Park (Ecuador).</p> <p>In order to achieve the conservation and sustainable utilization of nature and natural resources
column7: better information on the (economic) importance of natural areas alone
column8: however
column9: is not enough. Unless ecological information is structurally integrated in economic planning and decision-making
column10: solving environmental problems will prove difficult
column11: if not impossible. In the last section of this thesis
column12: the use of the function-concept as a tool in planning
column13: management and decision-making is therefore discussed in detail
column14: including the application in project-evaluation
column15: in environmental (or ecological) economics

column17: and in environmental education.</p>";"Groot

column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/459268;"Perspectieven voor de Bangert";"";"Voor een bijna 100 ha groot tuinbouwgebied in de gemeente Hoorn zijn de ontwikkelingsmogelijkheden in de agrarische sector nagegaan. Het oorspronkelijke verkavelingspatroon van lintbebouwing met smalle lange tuinen vormt veelal een beperking voor een doelmatige bedrijfsinrichting. Gebleken is dat een deel van de tuinders desondanks bedrijven heeft opgebouwd die een bestaansbasis vormen voor een aantal medewerkers. Het merendeel van hen wil het intensieve bedrijf in het gebied blijven uitoefenen. De nog talrijke extensieve bedrijven van ouderen kunnen bijdragen tot het oplossen van de ruimtenood van hun expansieve buren.";"Wijnen

column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/19632;"Development of an appropriate resource information system to support agricultural management at farm enterprise level : a prototype design for a decision support system in Moghan Agro-industrial Complex
column2: Iran";"";"<p>This thesis describes development of and experimentation with a prototype of an appropriate resource information system that improves decision making processes in farm management The system includes a geographic information system with a powerful process model that forms a decision support system for land use planning
column3: monitoring and evaluation at farm enterprise level. The land use planning sub-system uses a new concept and supports planning at tactical and operational levels. It consists of a crop growth simulation model that accurately estimates the productivity of each feasible land use
column4: a linear programming model that integrates the physical and socioeconomic information and designs the best suitable plan that maximizes the profit of the system under a given set of constraints (tactical plan)
column5: ad a spatial decision model that translates the tactical plan into an actual operational plan. The system illustrates the importance of process models in the integration of information from various disciplines and sources into management decisions
column6: and the application of geographic information systems in support of multiple objective decision problems.";"Sharifi
